fol.99v
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England
14 Au
g
1594. M
r
Bodeleye to my L.
Awnswere of yo
r
L. l
re
of
e 3 of August./
w
t
a Copy of
e
stat
l
re
to
M
o
s
Car
o
declar
y
g ther c
o
tent to put in order [.] shipp
14 Au
g
94
page.lettertext:
fol.98r
May it please yo
r
good L. For answear to yo
r
l
re
of
e 3 of this
p
nt
, I can signifie no more of
e states
preparation, then I have done already. They have
alwaies c
o
plained, and so they doe yet,
at they are not
made acquainted w
t
her
Hig
es
resolutions, knowing no-
thing yet for certaine of
e troupes
at shall be sent, of
e
number of her shippes, of
e time and place of their meeting
or ether needefull particularities. Nevertheles in regard
of their desire to second
at service, and
at they may
not be blamed for any backwardnesse heere, they have
already ordained, as I writte unto yo
r
L.
e 7 of this
moneth,
at of 10 of their best and greatest shippes,
ether all or some part shall repaire unto
e downes
, as-
soone as they are armed: but yet I am persuaded, un-
les
e certaintie be greater of her Ma
ties
proceedinges, then
appeereth yet unto them, they will but temporise at home,
and as I may conjecture, will not willingly be
e first,
that shall sette their shippes to sea. M
r
Caron, as I am
privatly informed, hath done them to witte,
at 14 of her
shippes are dispatched towardes
Plimmoth,
but yet
for
ought I can perceave, they are very litle sturred, w
t
at
advertism
t
from him, doubting as I doe suspect, that it
is but given out to tolle them faster forward: w
ch
per-
haps they thinke
e rather, because nothing is written of
those shippes unto me: although I had yo
r
l
re
by their
Agents conveiance
, and it was dated as lately as his.
It was my suite unto yo
r
L.
in all my former letters,
at for
e better perfourmance of my charge, and to satisfie
the states in
at w
ch
they require, I might have knowen
expressely, and directly, aswell w
at
forces her Hig
es
inten-
ded, for her part, to fournishe to this voiage, as w
at
she
doth expect, should be done by them heere: or in case
at
nothing were determined, to insinuat yet somwhat,
wherew
t
I might be able, to intertaine them heere
e while.
Howbeit yo
r
L. knoweth,
at from
e time
at I parted
from home, till this time, I had never any answear to
any point
at I proposed. Onely by yo
r
l
re
of
e 7 of July
I was enjoined to recommend unto
e states those par-
ticular demaundes w
ch
were delivered M
r
Caron, but
it was not signified to me, w
at
those demandes might import.
fol.98v
Uppon occasion wherof I am humbly to beseeche,
at in
these affaires of her Ma
tie
I may alwaies be instructed,
both precisely and by writing, to w
at
effect I shall nego-
tiat, and
at I may not be referred to knowe my message
of them, w
t
whome I should negotiat. For to be plaine in
this case, they doe very muche mervaile, and speake of it
often, to see me left so long heere w
t
out any information,
especially in these maters,
at are of suche consequence, and
for w
ch
I was sent expressely to them. They tell me
also roundly,
at considering I am present, it is not their order
to take
e onely notice of suche messages from their Agent,
and upon his report, to deale w
t
their
Provinces,
but
ei
must be recommended, as desired from her Ma
tie
by her
letters unto them, or by me
at am her servant, and pur-
posely imploied: and in effect, it will be hard for
her Hig
es
to be served as she would be, if there be not more
care of her ministers credit. I will not amplifie this
point, because yo
r
L. in yo
r
wisedome doth knowe w
at
is
meete, and will pardon me a litle,
at I speake w
t
some plai-
nesse, when I feele my self encombred w
t
e bourden of my
service, for want of due information. They have deli-
vered unto me a transcript of her Ma
ties
demaundes, in
w
ch
I doe not doubt, but they deale w
t
all sinceritie in
delivering me
e right demaundes: but yet I have reason
to be scrupulous, howe farre I should give credit to
at w
ch
they exhibit, where thinges are not specified to me in my
l
re
s. For I see very nowe
at in these demaundes, confer-
ring some pointes w
t
yo
r
L. l
re
, there is apparant va-
rance
. For where yo
r
L. doth certifie
at there were
12 shippes
at
e lest required of them, there are but
10
sette downe in writing, and likewise for
e place of their
Rendez vous, it is to them assigned to be at
Dover
, or the
downes
, where yo
r
L. declareth,
at they are looked for
at
Portesmouth
.
I have sent yo
w
heereinclosed a
copie of those demaundes, as I receaved them heere of them.
Moreover, I was in some doubt, as I writte unto yo
r
L.
whether they stoode still in force, because there folowed a
present countermaunde, w
ch
though yo
w
shewe to have bin
frustrat, by her Hig
es
approbation of M
r
Carons diligence,
in making his dispute up
o
e first motion, yet
at was
fol.99r
more then I was informed or then
e states at that
time would seeme to understand. What their
answear was heere to every point a part, I advertised yo
r
L.
e 21 of
e last, and I did it as becommed, w
t
a
faithfull relation, being ready upon my perill, to justifie
every worde w
t
e testimonie of
e states. And where
yo
r
L. alleageth,
at they had written to M
r
Caron
e 29 of
July, of their readiness at
at time, to send away their shippes,
w
t
out making any mention of doubt, or delay, I have for
mine owne discharge expostulated w
t
them, for answearing
me in one sort, and their Agent in an other: but they cleered
e mater p
nt
ly, declaring unto me,
at their maner was
to deale honestly and not doubblely, and so they had in
at
mater, shewing me for my better satisfaction
e copie of their
letter sent to M
r
Caron
e 29 of July, w
ch
I have caused
to be translated, and sent it heere unto yo
r
L. wherein,
howsoever M
r
Caron did explicat their meaning, there is
no suche promise made,
at they would send their succo
r
s
out of hand: and so it will appeere by
e issue of their
dealing. And as touching those doubtes, w
ch
they mo-
ved unto me, upon her Hig
es
demaundes,
ei were onely
suche as passed by way of communication between them
and me, and were not happely sette downe in
at letter to their
Agent, because they were not accepted as autenticall de-
maundes, M
r
Caron not knowing, nether at
at time
at he
writte his letter, nor in a good time
after
as he hath signified sins, but
at
e countermaunde had stoode. I have moved them
for 30 last of powder, as yo
r
L. desired
to have, but
e De-
puties of
Holland,
who are chief in this action, being absent
from
e Hage,
e rest put of their answear, till all come
together. I doe wonder very muche,
at
e taking
of
Groeninghen
came so lately to yo
r
L. For
e agreem
t
was made
e 11 of July, wherof
e newes comming hither
e
14 w
ch
was assoone as was possible
M
r
Gilpin
and I dispat-
ched presently a post, by whome he writte unto yo
r
L. and
I to
S
r
Robert Cecill
, having otherwise then occasion to send him
a letter of
e states, in answear to one
at was sent hther
from her Ma
tie
and consigned by him, to be delivered by
me: wherew
t
, as also
of
w
t
at occurrence of Groeninghen,
I did assure my self,
at he would acqaint yo
r
L.
fol.99v
The post, by whome o
r
l
re
s were sent, to
e end he
might prevent all other messengers, albeit
e winde was
very contrarie, hired purposely a passadge for
yarthmouth
and was
e first as he affirmeth, and I doe otherwise
understand
at brought
e tidinges into
England.
And
by him it was undoubtedly
at my
L. of Essex
might knowe
e certaintie, and not before: unles
at some body by pre-
sumption, had written
e newes before it was true.
And thus I take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
Au
g
14 1594.
Yo
r
L. most humble at commaundement. Tho. Bodley
